description:
Play the classic couple's game on TV! First the husbands answer a question … then the wives. Do your answers match up? Guys, do you remember the outfit your wife wore on your first date? Ladies, what is your husband's favorite song? Whether you just tied the knot yesterday or thirty years ago, The Newlywed Game DVD edition is classic couples fun for everyone!

—description from the publisher

You are top chefs competing at the world wide Omelette Championships. Your goal was to make the most elite food in the world, the dragon egg omelette. This year there's a twist, the dragons want to cook you! Can you gather the most eggs and avoid the dragons to make the biggest and therefore most scrumptious omelette?

This is a press-your-luck card game, where the object is to get three or more omelettes.

—description from the publisher

MAZE . . . is a game to entertain people of all ages. It is a two player game which combines strategy with chance.

The object of the game is to get all four of your playing pieces on the center dot (and off the board) before your opponent does.

Players start their men on opposite ends of the board. During the game, each player tries to get past the network of walls which his opponent is building against him. As he removes walls that are blocking him, he repositions them where he feels they will most hinder his opponent. Each tries to reach the center red dot (which is the only way off the board).

With both players heading for the center red exit dot they will often find themselves facing each other with no walls between them. These head to head encounters create exciting situations in which one or more pieces can be sent back to their respective "jail" corners to start over again.

The game is quite simple and lots of fun. The advantage can swing from one player to the other and back again many times throughout the entire game.

MAZE is [a wooden product] produced on home-made machines, silk-screened and assembled by hand. It is not a factory product, and is only offered in limited quantities.

—description from the inside of the box

The game to play with people you THINK you know--or that you WANT to know BETTER!!!!

Players must correctly predict how other players will answer their questions.

—user summary

"Depths of Courage volume 10" is a solitaire wargame on a proposed Italian mini-sub attack on New York Harbor during the summer of 1943. The active player takes on the role of the commanders of the three, two-man crew S.L.C. (Siluro a Lenta Corsa) Maiale (Pig) class and CA 2 mini-submarines. You must endeavor to overcome the US defenses and night-time visibility to inflict as much damage as possible before being killed, captured or escaping.

An Italian raid with by their frogmen was seriously planned and approved by both the Regia Marina and the Decima Mas. The planned raid was to have taken place in December 1943, but for game purposes I’ve moved it up to the summer of that year, before fascist Italy’s invasion and surrender.

A raid on the US was desirable for a number of reasons by the Italian naval high command. Potential targets in the Mediterranean were, by late 1942, well aware and experienced with the Italian raiders, and Allied defensive measures were increasingly deadly. The early 1942 German Operation Drumbeat U-Boat offensive, dubbed the “Happy Time”, exposed serious weaknesses and deficiencies in the US coastal and harbor defenses. A successful strike at the most prominent harbor in the US would be a tremendous psychological as well as military victory for the Axis cause. However, when it was proposed to their German allies in late 1941, Admiral Doenitz declined to support the operation with any U-Boats, but did approve sending any and all intelligence they came across to support Italian raid.

Unlike the frogmen raids conducted at Gibraltar, Alexandria, Algeciras and elsewhere in the Mediterranean, the raid on New York would also include the newest mini-submarine in the Italian navy’s arsenal, the CA 2. Armed with two torpedoes, these small submarines were so top secret they were never entered into the Regia Marina’s Order of Battle. Similar CA 5 type mini-submarines had raised havoc in the Black Sea and Adriatic, sinking numerous vessels and supporting blockades of enemy held ports. The CA 2 mini-sub and its crew, as well as the frogmen’s Maiale submersibles, would have to be ferried to the target area by a much larger submarine. The only one capable of doing so in the Italian navy was the fleet submarine Leonardo da Vinci. Modifications to its hull to transport the CA 2 were made in German occupied Bordeaux, and training of its crew and the raiders done in ultra-high secrecy in the Bay of Biscay. However, in May the Leonardo da Vinci was surprised and sunk by the British destroyer HMS Active and frigate HMS Ness with all hands. By that time Sicily was invaded and the Mussolini government soon over-thrown. The chaos that Italy descended to, and the new government’s later decision to cast their lot with the Allies, rendered the raid on New York to the dust bin of history.

Could the Italian navy pull off what no other nation had achieved since the War of 1812? I hope all who play Depths of Courage volume 10 learn and enjoy!

—description from the designer

DubbleKross is played in two phases: the first is the ELIMINATION PHASE where certain cards will be eliminated and their pegs placed in the PENALTY ZONE by the players rolling the dice; the second is the GAME PHASE where the remaining game pegs (representing all remaining eligible cards) are involved in a frantic race toward the WIN ZONE, also with players rolling the dice.

The objective of DubbleKross is to move one of the eligible game pegs from the "start zone" up through the "game zone" into the "win zone." Players holding the 4 cards corresponding to the winning peg collect a percentage of the pot depending upon how many of the four "win" cards each is holding. (one card gets 1/4, two cards-1/2, etc.)

—user summary

Simulate manouverings without financial responsibility. Simulate corporate politics.

The activity that teaches you to who to trust. The activity that needs no power or batteries. Keep active the mind of a 104 year old. Teach it to a 4 year old.

Corporate Affairs 301 may be played by 2 or 3 Stkrs (Stockholders). When 2 Stkrs are present, they shall manipulate Blue Company and Green Limited personnel primarily, and Red Corporation secondarily. When 3 Stkrs are present, Red Corp. personnel will be manipulated by the Red Stkr only.

Different coloured stick pins represent various company positions from Presidents to Grunts, each with different movement rules. A Stkr loses when the company loses its last Grunt.

—user summary

Word twisting fun to tease your tongue!

Can you say . . . "She says she shall sew a sheet"?

Now can you say it three times while patting your head and rubbing your tummy? That's the hilarious idea behind Tongue Twister.

The faster you can say a Tongue Twister, the further you move around the gameboard.

But wait a second. There's an extra "Twist". Just as you near the finish line one of your opponents can challenge you, sending you back a few spaces. But that's Tongue Twister the tongue-twisting, fast-paced, unpredictable and outrageously funny board game that will really tie an evening together!

—description from the publisher

This EXCITING, new game that is based on quotations is a must for all board game lovers. Enjoy many hours of fun being quizzed about quotes from the following six categories: Sports, History, Proverbs, Literature, Entertainment and General.

Because most questions offer multiple choice answers, you will find that this game will be played at a very rapid pace and with over 3,000 questions contained in this game, you may never know all the answers!

You will be entertained by quotes of W. C. Fields, be educated with excerpts from Shakespeare, be given a history lesson from the words of John F. Kennedy or just laugh at the always quotable Yogi Berra.'

—description from the publisher

In Oriflamme, the players find themselves in the middle of a medieval feud over the French royal crown. The King is dead! Long live the King! As heads of influential families, players strive to come to power with cunning and malice, power and strength, virtue and infamy. Their goal: the king's throne!

In this tactical card game, hidden cards are played in turn. By tactically uncovering and activating their effects, players can outdo or get them out of the way, because all players have the same goal in mind — to collect the most influence points for their family and thus win the game.

Your opponent has secretly filled in his Secret Code Grid. You have done the same. You ask him questions about his Grid, while trying to reveal little about your own. Can you duplicate his Code--before he unravels yours?

It will require strategy and cunning--and a dose of logical reasoning!

Then match wits with your opponent Super-CodeMaster, using any of the eighteen Grids that come with the game. Or play it by yourself, using the Solitaire Booklet also included. Either way, it's exciting, unique and challenging.

By the makers of the puzzle, LogicMaster.

—description from the back of the box

Each player takes a Grid Sheet (a sheet of two empty 25-square grids). On the top grid each writes his secret code. This consists of the letters A through E, each written five times. Write one letter in each square. The same letter may not appear more than one In a row or in a column. Therefore every row and column will contain each of the five letters.

You must discover your opponents secret code by using sums (made from the addition of the row and column numbers containing that letter) and knowing whether the letters in two named spaces are the same or different.

—user summary

This game will make you happy. 
Block Happy is a strategic, emotionally powered card game that's daring, different, and flat out fun. It’s the only game where you play it and feel it, because even though you’re playing a card game, you’re actually playing with your real emotions, which drives the gameplay.

Play with 70 unique emotional creature cards, and their various actions, to take turns showing, playing and finding emotions. The first player to seize all the happiness wins. This may sound simple, but other players want to take your happiness away, and so a tense and funny ‘battle of emotion’ begins, where you must keep control of your emotions, as well as controlling how other players feel too.

Block Happy will entertain and engage your emotions like never before, sparking more joy, fun and happiness into your day. 
Play it. Feel it. Believe it.

—description from the publisher

Between Checkers & Chess There's CROSSFIRE

Crossfire, 1. Lines of fire from two or more positions that cross one another; simultaneous fire along those lines. 2. An attack from two or more sources or directions

OBJECT: To collect as many points as possible while moving game pieces across board.
Points are collected by:
(A) landing on RED spots.
(B) capturing other game pieces and markers by landing on them.
(C) moving your game pieces into your opponents' home base.

—user summary

Tax is a 2-6 player card game using a deck containing four copies each of one through nine.


Deal five cards to each player and a sixth to the starting player. If playing with four, five or six players, deal a sixth card to the first and second players.
Place two cards face-up in the center of the table forming two separate discard piles.
On the side, place two cards face-up forming the communal card display.

Gameplay:
At the start of your turn, you must calculate the sum and the difference of the two cards atop the two discard piles.  At the end of your turn, you must be able to create one of those two values by performing one operation of addition, subtraction, multiplication or division between the two cards atop the discard piles at the end of your turn.

Taking Your Turn:
On your turn, you must make exactly one of four legal plays:

        Play a single hand card to the top of one of the discard piles.
        Play two hand cards, one to the top of each of the discard piles.
        Play one hand card to the top of a discard pile and one communal card to the top of the other discard pile.  Communal cards are not replenished when used.  A player is limited to using one communal card per turn but may use both communal cards over the course of the round.
        Fold and exit the round.  You can fold instead of performing one of the other actions.  If unable to perform one of the other actions, you must fold.
    


If the round has not ended, the next player in clockwise order who is still in the round takes his/her turn.

Round End:
If all other players have folded, the round ends immediately and the remaining player gains one point.

If a player plays his/her last card(s), the round ends immediately, and that player gains two points.

Collect the cards, shuffle, and perform the setup again.  First player rotates clockwise each round.

End condition:
The first player to reach or exceed a predetermined point value wins, for example 15 points.


Variant:
Want more information about your opponents' cards?  At the start of a round after receiving their hand of cards, all players must place a single copy of their highest and lowest cards on the table in front of them for all players to see.  These two cards are still considered to be hand cards.  Players use these two cards just like their regular hand cards and they are folded when the rest of the hand is folded.

—description from the designer

Quicksteel is a two-player fencing card game of cunning bladework and careful timing. In Quicksteel, you take on the role of one of two fencers.  Each fencer has a deck of 65 cards.  The decks are identical and consist of the varied combat maneuvers available to you.

Like blades, the cards of Quicksteel interact in a dance of skill and timing.  The lunges, parries and infinite combinations thereof allow players to enter a world where cunning and skill win the day…not strength or size.  The basic lunges and control cards are used to score points, the parries and movement cards to prevent touches, and the Specialty cards are used in combination with the previous cards for  spectacular and powerful effects.

True to international foil fencing rules, Quicksteel gives players a tabletop equivalent to actual fencing.  The goal of every match is to be the first to score 5 points/touches (Competition mode involves 3 matches requiring a total of 15 points to win).

Quicksteel grants players a glimpse into the world of fencing, into the mind of a fencer and into one of the most ancient forms of combat – the duel.

—description from the designer

NICE TRY is a competitive party game, in which 4 to 8 players face fast, crazy and hilarious challenges featuring mind, body and dexterity.

In over 50 challenges the players compete against each other in mini-games from different disciplines. With simple household items such as spoons or coins, everyone can playfully prove their skills.

The bidding phase before each challenge brings an exciting psychological component into the game, in which the players must estimate their own abilities and those of their fellow players in order to earn points.

The worst bid is kicked out. With the best bid you can earn the most points - but only if you succeed. If you overestimate yourself and fail, you collect minus points. The player with the most points after 8 rounds wins the game.

Do you earn the respect of your rivals, or do you just gain a gloating „NICE TRY!“?

—description from the designer

NICE TRY ist ein kompetitives Partyspiel, in dem sich 4 bis 8 Spieler (im Teammodus auch mehr) schnellen, verrückten und witzigen Challenges aus den Bereichen Cleverness, Geschick und Körpergefühl stellen.

In über 50 Herausforderungen treten die Spieler in Minispielen aus verschiedenen Disziplinen
gegeneinander an. Mit einfachen Haushaltsgegenständen wie Löffeln oder Münzen kann jeder spielerisch zeigen, was er drauf hat.

Die Gebotsphase vor jeder Herausforderung bringt eine spannende psychologische Komponente ins Spiel, bei der die Spieler ihre eigenen Fähigkeiten und die ihrer Mitspieler gut einschätzen müssen,um sich Punkte zu erspielen.

Das schlechteste Gebot fliegt raus. Mit dem besten Gebot kannst du die meisten Punkte verdienen – aber nur, wenn du Erfolg hast. Wenn du dich überschätzt und versagst, sammelst du Minuspunkte. Wer nach 8 Runden die meisten Punkte gesamelt hat, gewinnt das Spiel.

Verdienst du dir den Respekt deiner Mitspieler,
oder kassierst du nur ein schadenfrohes „NICE TRY!“?

—description from the designer (German)

Cancelletto (Hash) is a fast cooperative abstract game for 2 players, played on a modular board. The goal is to move all the meeples in their right cell before the board collapses.

—description from the designer

The players have to get their 5 caps from their stating line to the starting line of their opponent to win the game. Movement is in a straight line and determined by a die. If a cap gets on a black space it has to start again from the beginning.

Whenever a cap lands on an opponent cap, the later is blocked till the upper cap leaves again.

The game may be playes by 2 or 4 players.

—user summary

Auf dem Mond! is a light dice based game of lunar exploration, combined with trivia about space travel.
Game play proceeds by dice rolling: Players roll for movement points to reach the target on a moon track. Some points of the track require the answering of trivia. The player who reaches the target field first wins the game.

—user summary

ã‚¢ãƒŸãƒ¼ã‚´ï¼ (AMIGO!) is a Japanese speed word game. Players must determine the start letter of a word, then call out a word that fits the chosen theme.

Each player has two thumbs up cards. After a theme card and a word card card are turned up, players choose how to play their thumb cards. A thumb up is +1, a thumb down is -1. All players reveal their thumbs (you don't have to use both) and work out the correct number of steps.
4 thumbs up and 0 thumbs down equals +4 steps on the word card, giving the start letter. 
2 thumbs up and 4 thumbs down equals -2 steps on the word card (starting at the end of the word and going backwards), giving the start letter.

If the total of thumbs is zero, everybody shouts "AMIGO!"

The first player to get a word fitting the theme and start letter gives their answer. If correct, they get the theme card. If wrong, they hand one back as a penalty.

The player with the most theme cards collected by the end is the winner.
user summary

The big competition among the sorcerer's apprentices guarantees hectic and lots of fun. Who uses his wand most skillfully and leaves the ingredients for his potion hopping the fastest into his cauldron?

Hokus Pokus Flipibus is a dexterity game in which players have to flick tiles using a wand to make them hop off the board.

—user summary

Games are connecting people! Everywhere in our world there are exciting and funny children's games. Children play with marbles in Turkey, are clapping hands in Syria, and in Germany they knock down cans. With "Kinderspiele aus aller Welt" children not only get to know many new games from all over the world, they also take a look at other countries, experience a part of different cultures and discover many things in common.

The children look closely at pictures of a country and give a hint on which continent this country could be located. Afterwards everyone plays a mini-game together, which is played in this country. If you guess correctly, are lucky and show skill, you win!

With 24 small games from all over the world, children immerse themselves in other cultures and receive their first orientation on the world map. With vividly illustrated instructions on the playing cards, curious world explorers play independently and with lots of fun. A multitude of different game material makes the journey around the world a varied gaming experience.

—user summary

Physical Elements: Advanced is an advanced version of Four Elements that allows experienced players to build even stronger combinations.

This standalone game can be combined with Four Elements to create an even larger game.

A few locals found a cavern that has proven to be Auriferous (containing or bearing gold)! You and some of your friends decide to try your luck at striking it rich. However, you don’t have the knowledge or tools… yet! Upgrade your equipment and before you know it, you’ll be striking gold!

Auriferous is an easy to learn dice game for 2-4 players. Start off by just rolling five dice. Each turn, you'll be able to use those dice to upgrade your tools. Each tool allows you to alter your rolls and mitigate any bad luck. They might even let you find gold or steal it from other players!

If you can strike the most gold from the mine, you'll win!

—description from the publisher

In Wacky Widgets, the Gnome King needs help building contraptions in the Caves of Neverwhere for the benefits of his gnome clan and to help make products to sell to the other peoples of Westarland.

Wacky Widgets is a game for 1-4 players.  There are both competitive and co-operative variants that plays in about 20 minutes per player.

Complete with other players to build the most and the best roller race, lever linkage, water wash, and gear contraptions in the caves.  The cave is laid out in a 5x5 grid and has build cards (systems such as gears) laid out in it.  The build cards come in 4 system types, four connection types, and have systems on either side.  There are four types of schematics for things to build: Doohickeys, Whatsits, Thingamajigs, and Combobulations.  Use teams of gnomes to shove, flip, replan, and swap build cards to create systems that will meet the requirements of the schematics.  Earn victory points and build your support to get more gnomes to help you in future turns.  Keep building until one schematic deck runs out and the then the highest point total at the end of the round is the winner.

For a co-operative challenge, play the Gremlin Invasion variant.  The gremlins are invading the Caves of Neverwhere and getting in the way of your building plans.  Every turn, a new gremlin is added to the caves and the ones already there stir up more mischief.  Contend with over a dozen different gremlins like Masher Trasher, Fiendish Fil, Jammin' Sammy, and Head Dread.  All with unique and mischievous powers.  If you don't do anything about them they will overrun the caves.  Recruit gremlin hunters to chase the gremlins out of the cave, but be careful, chasing gremlins eats up valuable time and resources.

Plays essentially the same as the competitive game, but the goal is for the team to get to 100 points before time runs out.

—description from the publisher

Any word game requires using your bean, but the way to win Jabuka is to use the most beans in a spontaneous, fast-paced race to be the most prolific wordsmith. And here's the innovative twist: the coffee bean-shaped pieces with yellow characters can be turned to form different letters, changing j's into r's, m's into e's, and many more morphing moves. The totally twistable Jabuka alphabet even includes double letter combinations that change with their orientation. Use these alphabet chameleons to form new words or to hijack and transform existing words made by another player or team. The team that uses the most beans—straight up or strategically askew—wins the game (with a shout of "Jabuka" of course!). For 2-8 players, ages 8-108. 100% recycled wood, coffee bean shaped pieces in a natural mini burlap sack.

—description from the publisher

It is the Age of the Goremageddon and GRAXX is in a new wave of absolute carnage, brutality and ultra-violence. Along the highways, in hidden territories and throughout the wastelands, abandoned outposts sit, just waiting to be pillaged for everything that sits within. Thrashers engage these outposts, unsure of what awaits them inside: resources, weaponry, relics or even hordes of endless mutants, just lurking in every corner, waiting to feast on the flesh of those who wander within...

Mutant Outpost Massacre is a solitaire game of outpost-raiding in the post apocalyptic universe of Goremageddon (CPOP's flagship tabletop miniatures game; the third edition debuts soon). Players take the roles of 'thrashers' who raid outposts throughout the planet of GRAXX in the hopes of coming across rare items, resources, weapons and engage enemies in a non-stop massacre.

The game can be played in a single session, however, thrashers can continue their exploits in an ongoing career; the game only truly ends when your thrasher perishes. After a successful raid, thrashers gain experience, which is used to purchase new weapons, items and add skills, making them more powerful as they head into raid after raid after raid. Upon the final encounter of their raid, thrashers will face bosses, who will attempt to thwart their efforts to escape. Future expansions (coming soon) will add new encounters, new outposts, new enemies, new traps, bosses and so much more, making the game something players will want to come back to, time and time again.

We welcome you to the Mutant Outpost Massacre. May you live, die and thrash.

Goremageddon is heavily inspired by over-the-top violence, exploitation, gore, horror, humor and post apocalyptic films on the 1980s, as well as RetroWave and Thrash Metal music. Goremageddon is also CPOP's flagship project, made popular by a cult following and already headed into a third edition, due to release soon.

—description from the publisher

Hamsterdam is a tower defense game for the whole family. The water is rising and the only things standing between the sea and your town are a dam and a handful of brave hamsters. Place your hamsters on your dam and roll dice to see where the floods will strike. If you have a hamster there to protect your dam, they become part of your reinforcements. If the flood strikes an unprotected part of your dam, the flood waters seep through. Keep your town the driest and you win.

This new edition of Hamsterdam has updated artwork as well as a number of rules changes from the 2011 version.  The main differences in the rules are:

     You now pass two of your dam cards to your neighbors and get two in return which could cause you to end up with up to three of a single number.  
     The number of hamsters you get to defend your dam are based on which dam cards you keep and are passed.
     You may arrange your dam in any order.
     As you take on water, your dam now starts to collapse from the outside in.
     There are now 18 special hamsters to choose from instead of the original 6.


—description from the designer

Guess It is an easy-to-learn science game that plays like 20 questions"

Lay out up to 48 stunning photo cards--scaly reptiles, colorful minerals and very strange leaves.

Your friends secretly picks one from a matching Mystery Deck.

Can you guess the secret card by asking five "Yes-or-No? questions or less?

The fewer questions you have to ask, the better you score!

Also contains 8 other fun games:

Tic Tac Lotto
Animal, Vegetable, Mineral
Meat-Eater Roulette
Match, Set, and Win
Trample, Smother, Conk
One Minute to 12
My Snake
Chain Gang

The Music Game: Primary (Level A) is a fun board game for children that promotes a recognition and understanding of the basics of music. The Primary Music Game's easy and exciting approach encourages group participation and provides opportunities for creative musical expression. Charming drawings of animals and cartoon characters introduce the elements of music as a happy experience, which stimulates and develops the child's musical growth. Children learn music through fun activities.

Teachers/parents and children do not need any musical knowledge to play this game.

Used in the classroom or at home. The Primary Music Game makes an excellent teaching aid and can be adapted to any music program. Teachers/parents using this game will also find that children can learn music at their own pace.

OBJECT OF THE GAME:

The winner is the first group or child to reach the Finish position on the far right side of the game board. Players advance their coloured marker clips from left to right along the white and coloured piano keys (not the black ones) by rolling the die, and correctly responding to the Musical Category Cards.

THE MUSICAL CATEGORIES:

1: Musical Notes
2: Musical Keys
3: Musical Rhythm
4: Musical Signs
5: Musical Words
6: Music Makers

—description from the rulebook

The King of All Bards is a game of epic songs and dirty tricks for 3 to 6 players designed by Nikola R. Petrov and illustrated by Atanas Lozanski.

All your life you’ve chased the ultimate recognition a bard could receive – the Bard Crown. The money, the fame, they all mean nothing… Okay, they are pretty nice and the fastest way to prove your worth. The time has come! An epic sing-off in all the town’s pubs and taverns is your chance to get your hands on that sweet prize... and the title King of all Bards! Rehearse your best songs, prepare your nastiest tricks and get ready to smash the competition! It's showtime!

In The King of All Bards, you play the role of one of the eight distinct characters competing in a grand challenge. Your goal is to become the richest and most famous musician by amassing loyal fans and a fat purse of tips. To achieve this you have a repertoire of Song cards, as well as some more… dubious cards called Tricks. Playing the right songs for the right audience is crucial to building up a fan base and earning their gold, but employing the right tricks at the right moment can sabotage an opponent's performance and give you the upper hand.

Light up the stage! This is medieval showbiz!

—description from the publisher

First Blood is a collection of five 55-card preconstructed decks for introductory games of Vampire: The Eternal Struggle. These decks are simpler than tournament level decks, but showcase all the basic mechanics of the game. They are balanced, for a fun and exciting first try of Vampire: The Eternal Struggle. They are fully functional cards, ready to mix with cards from other sets.

To make Vampire: The Eternal Struggle more accessible to new players, Black Chantry will make these introductory decks available to retailers at a reduced price compared to our other products.

Clan Tremere are vampiric warlocks, masters of rituals of Blood Sorcery. Their powers make them arrogant and deadly, and they always lust for more occult lore.

This deck hits with a “bruise and bleed” tactic, trying to scare off blocking attempts with superior combat skills. It has a strong defensive module based on the Auspex discipline.

—description from the publisher

First Blood is a collection of five 55-card preconstructed decks for introductory games of Vampire: The Eternal Struggle. These decks are simpler than tournament level decks, but showcase all the basic mechanics of the game. They are balanced, for a fun and exciting first try of Vampire: The Eternal Struggle. They are fully functional cards, ready to mix with cards from other sets.

To make Vampire: The Eternal Struggle more accessible to new players, Black Chantry will make these introductory decks available to retailers at a reduced price compared to our other products.

Clan Nosferatu are horrors, grotesquely deformed by the Embrace. They hide in shadows and underground darkness, commanding animals as spies and allies in battle.

This deck is all-round – it has stealth to land key actions with precision, a strong reaction module and a brutal Animalism combat package.

—description from the publisher

An easy to learn and simple, yet strategic and addictive card game. Players race to discard their hand, in order to rise through the ranks of Bitch, Intern, Middle Management, Vice President and ultimately become “CEO”. 
You'll love battling for the CEO position while avoiding becoming the Bitch (the target of hilarious abuse). 
Business isn't fair… neither is this game, Bitch.

The game plays like an enhanced version of President/Scum/Asshole and contains: 
Numbered cards ranging from 0-10, Star cards from 0-10, Bitch cards, and Executive Order cards that change up game play each hand.

—description from the designer

Roll the dice and draw the symbols for the different MÄori tribes on your sheet. Place the symbols on your sheet so they connect totems with each other; create groups with three symbols to score (bonus) points.

Ka Pai is a quick game with no turns. Everyone must draw the symbols from the rolled dice. Will you be able to complete your sheet in such way that you score the most points?

—description from the publisher

Now players are trapped by mysterious magic in Dreamcatcher with Boogie man. There will be only one player that can escape from this magic. It is a person who pay the highest price of Dream coin to Boogie man within 3 Dream Circle.

Pirates Under Fire is an original, tactical, and dynamic two-player tile game that lasts 30 minutes and that can be played from 10 years old.

Each player is a pirate in charge of a fleet; each ship is numbered from 1 to 9, each of them having a special ability. The goal of the game is to deploy your ships to form combinations while performing their effects.

Players perform their turns one after another by laying a ship on a sea space. They apply the effect of the sea space and the effect of the ship tile. This is the main action. They can also perform an optional action: buying a mercenary ship by paying its cost. The game ends when each player has played 16 turns.

At the end of the game, players score victory points (VPs) for:
• the combinations made (three or more ship tiles laid side by side with identical numbers or forming a sequence of increasing or decreasing numbers),
• the ships laid in the opponent player's sea side,
• some mercenary ships, and
• the VP tokens collected during the game.

The player with the most VPs wins.

—description from the publisher

In Juices you assume the role of a Juice Master trying to make the best ones to make people happy. Your main goal is to do the highest amount on Juices, using the best combination of fruits and complements to make them unbeatable.

Juices is a hand-management, draft and pattern building game, where players try to create juices by combining the fruits that the play from their hand. Each player will have to make his own puzzle to maximize the amount of points of each of the juices that he do. You always give your card to the player in your right, but when you let him to do good Juices he will punish you.

Will you let him a good card just to take the one that you need? Or instead you will take a worse card just to prevent him on punishing you...?

These, and a lot more, in each game of Juices!

—description from the designer

In this game, you'll need to beat all three opponent's characters in order to win.
One player get the grey characters (the Magician, the Knight and the Archer), the other get the purple ones (the Dragon, the Dark Lord and the Skeleton). They are placed in a single line, grouped by color and each character begin with 10 out of 12 life points. All six characters's token are then drawn at random: this determines the play order.

Each turn, the player who owns the active character rolls 5 six-sided dice, up to 3 times, and can store as many dice as he/she wants between rolls (like in the classic game Yahtzee).
Dice showing 1, 2 or 3 must be used by two: one die used as an attack value, the other as a distance value. (For example : dice 1 & 3 can be used to deal 3 damage to a character directly adjacent to the attacker or to deal 1 damage to a character with a distance of 3.)
Die showing 4: allows two adjacent characters of same color to swap places.
Die showing 5: allows the active character to heal 1 damage (health bar is limited to 12 max).
Die showing 6: move the active character's token one space in the play turn order. This character will now play earlier in the upcoming turn order sequence.

As soon as a character's health hits 0, it is removed from the game, reducing the distance between the characters.
When a player has more characters still in play than his/her opponent, he/she plays with 4 dice instead of 5.

—description from the publisher

"The witch needs "guinea pigs" to try her new potions, and you, her loyal goblin minions, have been designated as forced volunteers for this occasion. It's not as terrible as it seems; okay, some of those potions may have a deadly effect… But the witch, always generous, has promised that one of you will leave unharmed, as a reward for her cunning, for her instinct and because someone will have to clean everything in the end..."

In this "party-goblin" of 4 to 10 players from 8 years of age and with a duration of approximately 15-20 minutes we will have potions, spells, antidotes, goblins and above all MANY LAUGHS!

—description from the designer

"La bruja necesita "conejillos de indias" para probar sus nuevas pociones y vosotros, sus leales esbirros goblins, habéis sido designados como voluntarios forzosos para esta ocasión. No es tan terrible como parece; vale, puede que algunas de esas pociones tengan un efecto mortal… Pero la jefa, siempre generosa, ha prometido que uno de vosotros saldrá ileso, como premio por su astucia, por su instinto y porque digo yo que alguien tendrá que limpiarlo todo al final."

MAL TRAGO es un party-goblin para grupos de goblins de 4 a 10 goblins, a partir de 8 años de edad goblin y con una duración de 15-20 minutos. Pociones, conjuros, antídotos, GOBLINS y sobretodo ¡¡MUCHAS RISAS!!

—description from the designer (Spanish)

"Operation Rösselsprung" is a solitaire wargame simulation of the German airborne raid aimed to capture Tito in 1944.
It focuses on the action of the Fallschirmjäger, around the village of Drvar.
The player controls the German forces and try to stop the Yugoslav counter-attack.

Players take the role of bakers in a bakery all vying for the attention of the head baker. They must compete to add ingredients to as many recipes and bake as much bread as they can.

—description from the introduction

Setup involves two distinct decks of cards ("Ingredients" and "Recipes").  Players begin with a hand of "Ingredients" cards and a reservoir of tokens.  Three "Recipe" cards are played in a common area.  The game is played in turns, taken sequentially by players, as normal for a card game.  Play involves adding matching "Ingredient" cards to available "Recipe" cards in an attempt to complete a "Recipe".  Players earn points for playing "Ingredients" cards and completing "Recipe" cards.  The game ends when the "Recipe" deck is exhausted - the players with the most points wins.

Bread Bonanza Bakery was created for, and submitted to, Game Chef 2019.

—user summary

Players must do good deeds to defeat Fangoso, the corruption sticky  monster. If Fangoso kills one of the players, everyone will lose.

Players roll the dice to advance. When they fall into a Fangoso space, they take a card to know how many health points they lose.

When they fall into an Action space, they take a card and roll a D8 dice to find out how many health points Fangoso loses. The highest numbers correspond to the best deeds.

—description from the designer

“We must move that ore, and keep it moving!” –Spokesman for the United States Army Engineers, Detroit Free Press, March 8, 1942.

“There is going to be a tremendous movement of iron ore in the Great Lakes regions.” U.S Interior Secretary, Harold Ickes to the Solid Fuels Advisory War Council, Toronto Evening Telegram, March 11, 1942.

Following the attack on Pearl Harbor the US was suddenly thrust into World War II. Every manufacturing concern was now faced with the daunting tasks of converting production facilities to wartime goods at levels never before seen during peacetime. The focus on the US steel industry was of particular concern, as nearly all weapons and wartime support derived from their factories and workers. However, nearly all of the leaders and owners of the US steel industry were either very dismissive or even obstructionist of the prospects the US would become involved in the war, and President Roosevelt’s attempts to ready the country for war.

Nearly all of the iron ore, as well as much of the limestone, needed for the steel industries were shipped over the Great Lakes from the iron ore fields in Minnesota to the ports at Chicago, Detroit, Toledo, Cleveland, Buffalo in the US and Hamilton, Ontario in Canada. From those ports the iron ore was shipped by rail to the steel mill complexes in Gary, Detroit, Cleveland, Youngstown, Pittsburgh, Buffalo and Hamilton. The massive ore carriers that plied the waters of the Great Lakes sailed from mid-April to late November when weather and water conditions permitted. However, it soon became apparent that the amount of iron ore laid up in late November 1941 for use during the winter and spring was totally inadequate for the war effort. The US “arsenal of democracy” would be essentially shooting blanks due to shortages of steel and idle plants if the shortfalls of iron ore and limestone were not quickly addressed. In a bold decision it was decided to mobilize at least part of the Great Lakes ore carrier fleet to allow it to begin loading and delivering the badly needed iron and limestone ores a month ahead of the regular start of the sailing season. Besides the severe challenges of the late winter weather, with severe storms, ice bergs and jams and frigid waters, finding officers, crew, and dock workers to work at the loading and unloading ports would be difficult as wartime drafts and the demands for materials and men from other wartime challenges were encountered. Historically, the “Winter Fleet” led to 1942 setting all-time new records in the delivery of ore via the Great Lakes, as well as production of steel. But the risks and costs were high.

Breaking the Ice is a solitaire play game on the Great Lakes “Winter Fleet”. The player will have to allocate valuable resources and deploy the car ferry ice breakers to support the ore fleet in the mission of delivering the most ore to the production ports as possible, with a minimal amount of damage to the fleet as possible. Can you do as well, or better, than your historical counterparts?

—description from the publisher

This is a unique game which mixes elements of Connect Four and Twister.

The game board is a unit that holds 21 tiles (3 rows of 7), but only the centre 9 tiles are visible to the players. New tiles can be added to the game board on either end, and into any of the rows. Each time a new tile is added to the game board a tile is ejected from the other end of the same row.

The tiles display either a body part (nose, forehead, ear, shoulder, elbow, belly button, back, knee or foot) or "Bent Out of Shape."

On a player's turn (or the team's turn if playing in teams), the player rolls the die and takes the corresponding number of tiles from the facedown pile next to the board. The player then inserts the tiles into the game board, from either side and into any row. After they have inserted the new tile, the display of the 9 tiles at the centre of the board will have changed. The player will then attempt to score the body part that is displayed in the very centre of the board.

To score the body part in the centre of the board, the other player(s) will announced the eight body parts surrounding the centre square, two at a time, starting from any corner and moving clockwise around the square of eight body parts. As the other player(s) announces the body parts, the playing player/team must connect the two body parts together by connecting the parts on each other's body or by using their hands. While holding this position, the next two body parts are announced and must be added to the current pose.

If the team is successful at connecting all the body parts at once, they score the body part in the centre square. If the team is unsuccessful at connecting together all of the body parts, or fails to hold the pose throughout the turn, they score nothing. Players/teams are given two chances to complete the pose.

If any of the 9 tiles displayed in the game board displays "Bent out of Shape" instead of a body part, then one member of the team must try to link all of the body parts by himself/herself. Because this task is more difficult, if they succeed they can score any body they wish.

The first team to score all nine different body parts wins.

—user summary

A drawing game where your body is the canvas. Take an INK card. Take a BODY card. Choose the PLAYER you want to INK. Players race to guess what the tattoo is and earn points for correctly guessing and drawing. In the party game where everyone gets to TATTOO and be TATTOOED, how will you leave your mark?

—description from the publisher

"The tour de France by young age drivers". 
The board game theme - Take a Tour de France rally by car.
The fastest driver wins the game.
It is typical spin and move board game.
Great looking metal cars representing automobiles of the time.

—user summary

A card game with numbered cards, action cards, jokers, and special cards. 
On your turn, you will play a card to the open stack or draw a card from the closed stack. There are rules for which cards can go on top of each other, and you win by getting rid of all your cards.

—user summary

A quiz game with a stack of cards each with six questions about the 1970's.

At the beginning of the game, the players decide how many points to play to.

On a player's turn, he rolls the die and the player to his left asks him the corresponding question. If he answers correctly, he gets the card as a point. If his answer is wrong, the other players may hit the bell to answer the question and get the card and the point if correct.

The game ends when a player has the agreed number of points.

—user summary
